prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

text.response:
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Not when my tongue aches to echo a borrowed view.
You dwell not in shouts nor in easy acclaim,
But in still, silent chambers untroubled by fame.

To know you is practice—a daily intent,
An ear to the whisper, a will to relent.
For honesty stumbles when habit is weak;
Only with listening can I truly speak.

So Truth, walk beside me, reshape what I know,
Teach my small soul to bend, to bow low.
Let words not betray what my spirit won't do—
Truth, I can speak you if first I hear you.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Not plucking your feathers to build pretty lies,
But folding your silence into the seams of my day,
Making of you a song only courage dares hum.

How long, I wonder, have I muddied your waters
With eager pronouncements and echoing boasts?
Yet you ripple, unwavering, quiet and clear,
Beckoning my heart to the patient arts—
Of pausing, of hearing, of being sincere.

Truth, may I find you not in thunders of certainty,
But in the hush between words, and in honesty's hue.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Like the dawn drinks silence before it kindles blue.
If I hush the din of ego, the rustle of pride,
Perhaps in your shadow I learn to reside.

To speak you, sweet Truth, is no act of chance—
It is humble devotion, a patient romance.
With ears finely tuned to the tone of your song,
My lips will find words where the true belong.

So I will make listening my fervent art,
For only then, Truth, can you flow from my heart.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Letting each word rest gentle upon my mind’s dew.
Too swift are the judgments, the tales we compose,
While your quiet counsels drift soft as a rose.

You are no captive of moment or fashion or rage;
You dwell in the pauses, in the turning of the page.
Let me welcome your whisper, endure the unease,
So when I must speak, I may do so with ease.

For Truth is a habit, a silence we tend—
The more that I listen, the more I ascend.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Patient and careful, as seasons break through.
Not snatched in the moment of fever or doubt,
But learned in the quiet, when noise is shut out.

To utter you boldly is easy and cheap—
Yet living your lessons demands I go deep.
I will school both my heart and my ears to attend,
So truth from my lips is no means, but an end.

May I never mistake fleeting impulse for you—
Truth, I will speak you by hearing you true.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Your footsteps echo in the mind, your form comes into view.

If only ears are open, and will to witness grows,

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Like a river that learns from its bed the shape of flowing through.

And honest speech blossoms where the heart has learned to need.
To speak the truth is discipline, a ritual, a song—
Its verses taught in moments where reflection lingers long.
May my listening be patient, so my words ring ever clear—
For truth once learned in silence is what all the world will hear.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
An inward pledge to greet your voice, steady and new.
Before I lend my lips to words that seek the light,
May I befriend the silence and welcome what is right.
For honesty is practice, a craft the spirit hones,
Attending to your murmurings when I am most alone.
If listening becomes my nature, then truth will shape my speech—
And all my words, well-founded, will travel where you reach.

text.response:

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Beyond the murmurs of comfort and the pretty half-true.

If I pause in humility, heedful and clear,

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

text.response:

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

text.response:

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

And if I should dare to speak,

You unfurl, fragile and real, impossible to hide.
So let my tongue serve my listening soul:
Words not for echo, but for echo’s end.
Truth, may you dwell where my ears are open—

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

No grand declaration brings you near,

When I have made you my company, hour by hour,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

text.response:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Could lure my spirit to awake,
No softer sun, no fairer tree,
No star’s sweet promise could I take.

The wind that stirs the poplar high,
The dawn that bends with honeyed light—
Are only perfect if you’re nigh,
Your name transforming day and night.

So in this trembling heart abide,
For worlds and wonders I would flee,
And choose, with hope and arms flung wide,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I brave storms that darkly roll,
Nor bargain with eternity
For lesser payment of my soul.

All treasures earth and sky contain,
Pale diamonds set on velvet sea,
Dwindle and blur, compared again,
Dear love, to nothing less than thee.

So let the world be rich or wild,
Its glories gather, spill, and flee—
I’d trade it all, with joy and smile,
For dear, enduring, only thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
My days unspool, my dreams unwind—
A single wish that sets me free,
A melody within my mind.

The cities flicker in the dusk,
The oceans speak in whispered blue,
But through the twilight and the husk,
My thoughts are always pulled to you.

So may I wander, search, and strive,
Across the land, beneath the sea,
For only with your hand in mine,
Dear love, I find the heart of me.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Could sway the tides of fate I face,
Nor steer the winds that carry me
Toward your silent, sacred grace.

The gilded halls of distant kings,
The poet’s prize, the warrior’s shield,
Seem faded, fleeting, empty things,
Unless to you my arms may yield.

So, take this vow across the night—
The world may bargain, claim, and plea;
Yet all my longing, hope, and light,
Dear love, are only found in thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
I’d cast my shadows far away,
And sing upon the highest tree,
Awaiting promise of your day.

For gems and gold I do not yearn,
Nor fortune’s fleeting, fickle grace—
My restless soul will only turn
To trace the sunlight of your face.

So when the stars spill silver rain
And whisper truths the heart can see,
I know I live, I breathe, I reign—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
Would I surrender dreams at sea,
Let silent wishes fill the air,
And anchor hope with tender care.

The moon may call with silver eyes,
The world may tempt with sweet disguise;
Yet only you, in storm or calm,
Can hold my soul within your palm.

So take these words, a faithful plea:
I live for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I betray the dawn,
Nor gather dewdrops from the grass
When waking you are gone.

The rose that climbs against the wind
Does so to meet your face;
A thousand moments intertwine
And bend to your embrace.

I barter neither hope nor peace,
For naught, unless it's true;
Dear love, for nothing less than thee—
My every breath is you.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Could morning bear such golden hue,
Nor evening's hush become a prayer
For stars to shine their way anew.

Upon the trembling line of fate
Where hope and doubt entwine,
My heart inscribes your sacred name—
No greater cause, no grander claim.

The world may tempt with jeweled crowns,
Yet finds me humbly kneeling here:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee—
This soul remains sincere.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I give up the summer’s sky,
The waltzing breeze, the honeyed air—
All yield beneath your gentle eye.

The morning waits to catch your smile,
The night retreats before your gaze.
Each heartbeat learns a different tune
When you transform the commonplace.

And so I wander, hope in hand,
A pilgrim drawn by certainty:
There’s no pursuit nor dream for me,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

text.response:

text.response:

Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I wander lost and long;

Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,
I scale the dawn with steady breath;

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I traverse these restless years;

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

text.response:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee—  
No summer sun, no endless sea,  
No distant star in midnight’s crown  
Could lure me far or hold me down.  

Thy voice alone stirs morning’s air,  
Thy touch can spark the twilight flare.  
Through seasons lost and time set free,  
I live and breathe for naught but thee.  

O let the world with treasures brim,  
With golden song and seraph hymn—  
Yet empty all these riches be,  
If not inspired, dear love, by thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee  
Would I uproot my life and roam—  
Across wild plains and raging seas,  
To follow you, to find my home.  

No wealth or glory tempts my heart;  
The world’s acclaim I’d let depart.  
In every sigh, in every plea,  
The answer comes: for naught but thee.  

Let mountains shift, let tempests cry—  
So long as you and I draw nigh,  
No power could unmoor my plea:  
Dear love, I give my soul for thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee  
Shall I dare to dream or soar;  
Neither fame nor destiny  
Could open longing’s hidden door.  

You are the breath the lilies claim,  
The hush that calms the twilight’s frame.  
All joys unspoken dwell with me—  
If only to be loved by thee.  

So take my hand, the path is wide,  
Where shadows shrink and stars abide.  
In every choice and memory—  
Dear love, I choose nothing but thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee  
Could stir the hush in restless night,  
Or turn the dark to melody  
That rises with the morning light.  

I sought for wisdom, gold, and song—  
For worlds where endless gardens grow,  
But none among the fleeting throng  
Could grant the grace thy heart bestows.  

All glories dim, all ages fade,  
Except for what in thee I find:  
The simple, sacred vows we made—  
Dear love, my solace, soul, and mind.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee  
Would hope be given breath or birth,  
Nor would I strive for victory  
In anything of lesser worth.  

All beauty bends itself to you,  
The morning's blush, the dusk's refrain.  
No poet’s quill, no painter’s hue  
Could tell what words can scarce contain.  

Let every promise, soft and sweet,  
Be testament to what I see—  
No fate, no force could be complete  
If not for love, for love of thee.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

text.response:

Of fervent vows, the promised land

For you, I brave the distant night,

Yet every dawn, your soul I see—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Shall my heart bend, nor will I flee.
The world may offer sun and gold,
Yet your sweet whisper, all I hold.

The meadow bends beneath the sky,
Yet never bows as deep as I
Who kneel, adrift on memory—
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I scale the tallest sea,
Or plant my hope on barren land,
Trusting only in your hand.

For kingdoms fall and riches flee,
And even time will fade from me—
But steadfast as the rooted tree,
I vow my heart for none but thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Could light such fire inside of me;
Not autumn wind nor summer rain
Could stir this deep and sweet refrain.

Through tempests wild, my thoughts are free—

Of all the world may give to me,

Dear love, for nothing less than thee

Let passing days and years agree—
My soul was shaped for none but thee.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

text.response:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee,

For all the world is lesser fare,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I entrust my silent prayers,

Could ransom joy or quell the ache;
All riches gathered from afar
Are empty for my longing's sake.

So take this heart—its trembling plea—
And keep it safe in constancy,
For all I am, and wish to be,
Dear love, is nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Could draw the night from weary skies,
Or spark the hush of memory

Through shadowed halls of whispered past,
Your voice still drifts—a golden chime;
With every echo, hold me fast,

For fleeting fancies fade away,

No kingly gift nor fortune's store

Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
I barter days and dreams unseen,
Trace every star’s eternity

Let cities rise, let tempests fall,

Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee
Would I unfasten heart and soul,

Your name the light that guides my way,
Your voice the call that draws me home.

No ruby rare, no endless gold,

My treasure’s found within your fold,
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

So let the world in chaos spin,
Let storms amass upon the sea;
Within your arms, my truth begins—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Dear love, for nothing less than thee'

text.response:
Dear love, for nothing less than thee—  
The sun on high could never warm,

It is thy gaze, thy voice, thy light—  
For thee alone, my soul’s esteem.  
The golden fields, the starry seas,  
Hold lesser wonders, small and true,  
But in this world, my heart agrees—  
None hold my gaze as deep as you.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee  
Would I chase the moon across the tides,  
Or gather dawn in trembling hands  
And wear the storm as gentle guides.  
For every step upon the earth  
Is just a path that leads to you—  
A whispered wish in hopeful birth,  
A secret promise made anew.  
All that I am and hope to be,  
The song I hum, the dream I see,  
They flower bright and wild and free,  
Dear love, for nothing less than thee.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee  
Would roses bleed their velvet red,  
Or midnight spill its reverie  
Upon the quiet path we tread.  
Not gold nor fame could dare persuade  
My wandering heart from where you lie—  
A thousand dawns would slowly fade  
If not for you beneath the sky.  
So let me be the breeze you breathe,  
The gentle hush of falling rain—  
For love, for you, my soul believes  
That joy and sorrow are not in vain.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee  
Would I give all the songs I know—  
Let silver strings break patiently,  
Let time slip softly as the snow.  
No star above, nor secret prayer,  
Could ever tempt my soul away;  
Your name, the only word I bear,  
I carry with me, night and day.  
All worlds, all wonders, yet I see,  
Reflect but glimmers, pale and fleet;  
For only you can set me free—  
My heart, your harbor, still and sweet.

Dear love, for nothing less than thee,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

text.response:
'Twas noontide of summer, the fields in a hush,
A golden-soaked silence, the air thick and plush.
Sunlight unfurling on petals and stone,
Beneath a vast sky that feels wholly my own.
The butterflies dance in the simmering light,
Their wings painted echoes of purest delight.
A breeze lazy-spun weaves through emerald hair,
In the noontide of summer, all burdens laid bare.

'Twas noontide of summer, when shadows dissolve,
When ripened wheat waves as mysteries evolve.
A distant dog barking, cicadas in tune,
And the road ripples under a silver balloon.
My bare feet on earth, cooled by recent dew,
Heart swelling with all that I still long to do.
The world holds its breath in that radiant glare—
At the noontide of summer, possibility’s air.

'Twas noontide of summer, when time dared to pause,
And light drew mosaics through trembling gauze.
Tall grasses whispered of secrets now told,
Their laughter was sunbeams spun from old gold.
A river of sky flowed quiet and deep,
And in its bright current, dreams woke from their sleep.
The pulse of the earth was a soft, steady drum—
Noontide of summer, when everything’s young.

'Twas noontide of summer, the ripe world aglow,
Dragonflies dart where wild lilies grow.
Air sticky with promise and distant refrains,
Carried on currents that ripple the grains.
My thoughts drift with dandelion fluff in the heat,
And hope lingers fragrant and sweet.
Nothing but now, sunlight and clover,
In the noontide of summer, forever turns over.

'Twas noontide of summer, on lanes made of fire,
The sun reigned in glory, ascending ever higher.
An orchard's soft breathing, the apples in blush,
A lull in the chorus, a magical hush.
Dreams spilled like honey, slow rivers of gold,
On fields where the tales of the daylight are told.
To linger and listen, the hour all a-shimmer—
The world wide awake at the noontide of summer.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: ''Twas noontide of summer,'

text.response:
'Twas noontide of summer, when shadows were still,
And gold spilled like honey on valley and hill.
The air was a shimmer of heat on the lane,
The dragonfly dancing, ignoring the grain.
Cicadas in chorus strummed sweet, lazy tunes,
And poppies were drowsing by silent lagoons.
With languor, the earth seemed to quietly yearn
For thunder’s bold promise or coolness’ return.
Yet under the hush of a sun-blotted dome,
I wandered in meadows, as free as a poem.

'Twas noontide of summer, when sunlight is fire,
Where laughter of swallows lifts higher and higher.
The world in its languor, reclining and slow,
Finds dreams in the glimmer and flowers aglow.
Old willow trees doze by the slow-braided stream,
While daisies lean over and idly daydream.
A moment suspended in sultry embrace—
The heart of the summer, a soft, golden space.
The hum of the bees weaves a warm lullaby,
Under the pulse of a cloud-freckled sky.

'Twas noontide of summer, the air thick with song,
Butterflies drifting on breezes along.
Children lie laughing on carpets of green,
Inventing adventures their eyes haven’t seen.
Tomatoes are blushing and sunflowers spin
To the tune of the wind, whisper-thin.
The distant mirage blurs the faraway pines,
Each second expanded by warm, lazy lines.
In the heart of the day, time tenderly yields
To the bright, drowsy magic of long, golden fields.

'Twas noontide of summer, the light at its crest,
Each petal and pebble agleam in its vest.
Cloverfields basked in a velvety hush,
A red kite asleep in a sky turned to plush.
Green-apple breezes swept secrets along
While robins rehearsed an invisible song.
Stone walls breathed heat from a hundred warm days,
And shadows shrank small in the luminant blaze.
Beneath this pure stillness, I carried the proof
That summer’s bright noontide is living, not youth.

'Twas noontide of summer, with all things aglow,
A sapphire above and the grasses below.
Foxgloves stood silent, like sentries of light,
Guarding the hush of the long, sultry night.
Bluebells were drifting on rivers of breeze,
And whispers of warmth curled the limbs of the trees.
Time seemed to falter in this golden reprieve,
With secrets that sunlight alone can conceive.
I lingered and listened, while everywhere, free,
Summer’s bold noontide was singing to me.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

text.response:
This anger burns deep within,
A furnace stoked by hidden pain,
Beneath my skin it whispers, thin—
A flicker forged in shadow’s chain.

Molten words I never said
Swirl like embers in my chest;
I bite them back, afraid they’d spread,
Yet still I feel them, never rest.

This fire dances, sharp and sly,
Demanding breath, a gasp, a sigh.
But as I let its heat unfurl,
May anger forge, not burn, my world.

This anger burns deep within,
A tempest trapped under bone and skin.
Each heartbeat echoes a war drum’s cry,
Stoking embers that refuse to die.

Silent thunder in midnight veins,
Heavy with unspoken pains.
If only tears could quell the fire—
Or soothe the ache of buried ire.

Yet in its heat, perhaps I’ll find
A kindling of courage, unconfined,
To rise from ashes, and begin—
A new flame where I let light in.

This anger burns deep within,
Fierce as a comet in midnight’s skin,
It claws at ribs, seeking air—
A captive beast’s wordless prayer.

Silent volcano, capped so long,
Your pressure gathers in a song
Of what was lost, what might have been,
Red rivers rolling under the skin.

Let me shape you into steel—
Not to wound, but help me heal;
From the crucible I ascend,
Burning, yes, but stronger in the end.

This anger burns deep within,
Molten lava, trapped in stone.
It twists my thoughts, and gnaws my grin,
Yearning to be seen, to be known.

A storm beneath a calm façade,
Lightning flaring in silent eyes,
I hold it close—a battered guard—
Letting none hear my hidden cries.

Yet from the fire, sparks can fly,
Seeds of truth too fierce to quell.
Maybe, one day, I’ll let it die,
And drink from peace’s cool, clear well.

This anger burns deep within,
A caged fire, restless, thin,
Threading veins with molten spite,
Guttering hope, strangling light.

How quietly it fills the void—
Words unsaid, trust destroyed,
Fists unclenched, but spirit taut,
Haunted by the battles fought.

And yet, this fury has its place—
It kindles courage, stokes the chase,
And though I burn, I will begin
To rise renewed, flames within.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'this anger burns deep within,'

text.response:
This anger burns deep within,
A river of coals beneath my skin,
Each word, a match; each look, a spark,

Silent I walk through the halls of doubt,

In shadowed corners I confide
The molten ache I cannot hide.

Yet from this blaze, a light will rise—
A furnace forging new disguise,
From wrath to strength, from pain to grace:
I build anew from the smoldered place.

This anger burns deep within,
Not thunder, not storm, but a drumbeat
Caged behind ribs—my skin, my kin—
An ancient blaze refusing defeat.

It simmers and crackles in shadowed bone,
Refusing peace, it claims its throne,
A fuel for change, a voice to defend,
A wild uprising I must befriend.

When the dawn arrives and the fever wanes,
What is left: scarred gold, unbroken chains.
Through every ache, I rise and spin—
Forged by the fire that dwells within.

This anger burns deep within,
Molten, hidden under porcelain calm,
It sizzles on old wounds and new sins,
A searing pressure—gentle hands become balms.

Crimson threads lace through memory's door,
Whispering truths I'm too proud to ignore.
If only this rage could speak or sing—
Would it scorch the night or soften its sting?

I let the flame simmer, learning to hold
The wild inferno as part of my soul,
Molding the blaze to light the path in the dark:
The power to heal is a gift from the spark.

This anger burns deep within,
Fierce and silent, clothed in sin.
It colors my sight, taints my days,
Glowing quietly in unseen ways.

Unleashed, it roars, devours all reason,
Twisting joy in and out of season.
But I cradle it gently, daring to tame,
Wishing for peace where now is only flame.

Through time’s patient hands I may learn,
That not all fires were meant to burn;
Sometimes the hottest coals, denied,
Are simply aching hearts—untied.

This anger burns deep within,
An ember untouched by gentle rain,
Silent but bright beneath my skin—
A spark of sorrow, a flash of pain.

I walk with it, shadow to stride,
Letting it guide but never decide.
Like a lantern glimmering in the gloom,
It leads me out of every tomb.

And when at last it dims to light,
I will thank the fire for the fight;
For without the burn I’d never begin
To rise from ashes—new, again.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'For the first time in my life'

text.response:
For the first time in my life,
I noticed how dawn wears gold—
light threading the quiet air,
washing regrets from the cold.

I listened to silence sing softly
through unopened letters and doors,
a hope rising shy in the morning,
untangling grief from the floors.

For the first time, wonder spilled
from a teacup of trembling hands;
I held the sky like a secret—
uncertain, but daring to stand.

For the first time in my life,
I felt the wind tell me its name,
as petals whispered on the avenue—
old joys kindled, no longer the same.

I watched the shadows bloom and fade,
not fearing the soft edge of night;
with each breath, the world turned gentler—
I became the traveler and the light.

For the first time in my life,
I danced where no one could see,
Unburdened by years of silence,
Wild as a whispering tree.

Sunbeams caught in my laughter,
Fears fluttered away like birds.
Freedom filled my open hands,
Brimming with unwritten words.

For the first time in my life
I saw the world turn soft,
Clouds pirouetting through windows,
Moments lifting me aloft.

Each heartache became lighter,
An echo in a vast new hall.
I met my reflection smiling—
Not afraid, for once, to fall.

For the first time in my life,
I stood at the edge of myself,
Eyes open to quiet marvels,
Casting doubt to the shelf.

Each ordinary gesture—sudden magic;
Rain was laughter, shadows play,
The mirror greeted a stranger
Awakening to this day.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'For the first time in my life'

text.response:

For the first time in my life,

Tumble wildly through my chest,
I taste the world, raw and clear,
And know at last what it means to rest.

For the first time in my life,
I stepped out, leaving shadows behind—
The world blazed wide, uncaged and bright,
As if awakening my mind.

I felt the sun, not through the glass,
But on my skin—unveiled and true.
Each breath became a second chance,
A landscape blossomed into view.

The hush inside me broke in song,
A melody unknown, yet mine;
For the first time, I belong—
At peace in joy, in fear, in time.

For the first time in my life,
Silence doesn’t sting with doubt,
Instead it feels like open space,
A garden for my dreams to sprout.

My hands are empty, yet unafraid—
No baggage left from yesterdays;
The sunrise smiles, the night has paid
Its ransom, bright with dawning rays.

For the first time, hope feels light—
No heavier than dandelion fluff;
I hold my future in new sight—
For the first time, love is enough.

For the first time in my life,
I watched the sky bloom purple, wild,
My heart a restless paper kite,
My soul the laughter of a child.

For the first time, stars were not
So distant—just a wish away;
The ordinary lines forgot
The weariness of yesterday.

I found myself in falling rain—
A gentle baptism, washed anew;
For the first time in my life,
I dared to trust the world—and you.

For the first time in my life,
I listened close to who I am,
Unraveled webs of borrowed strife,
Let go of all the "should have" plans.

The mirror showed not scars or tears,
But stories written in my skin,
Of all the dreams denied by fears,
Now singing softly from within.

For the first time, I turn to me,
A friend, a witness, not a foe;
The future open, wild, and free—
For the first time, I let go.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

text.response:
War's a joke for me and you,
In marble halls and velvet blue.
Maps are chessboards, pieces move,
Distant pawns for us to prove.

Cups are clinked as cannons boom,
Plans are drawn in gilded rooms.
Safe from cries of loss and pain,
We laugh beneath our gilded rain.

Yet beyond our wit and jest,
Smoke and ash consume the rest.
We forget what war can do—
War’s a joke for me and you.

War's a joke for me and you,
In drawing rooms where tea is brewed.
We make our wagers, toss our puns,
Unscarred by any setting sun.

Outside the glass, the fields ignite—
But here, it's games and late-night bites.
We jest of banners, blood, and pride,
But none have seen a brother die.

So let us laugh in sheltered halls,
While others march at bugle calls.
Perhaps, one day, the jest will end,
When war returns to take a friend.

War's a joke for me and you,
Safe from thunder, fire, and dew.
From balcony we view the fight,
We play with words and sip our night.

War’s a story on the screen,
A topic tossed in magazine,
But in our hands, no powder, lead—
Our battles live in books we’ve read.

Yet somewhere, laughter dies away,
Where sons and fathers fall each day.
Oh, war's a joke, for those not caught,
Within the fire of what we've wrought.

War's a joke for me and you,
A tale retold when day is through.
We banter, scoff at history's pages,
Unmoved by names, by loss or ages.

We turn the globe and draw new lines,
Never crossing warning signs.
To us, it’s play—a whispered dare—
But outside, shells scream through the air.

So while we jest, and chuckle, too,
Let's remember laughter's due.
For somewhere else, a world away,
War claims lives we made a play.

War's a joke for me and you—
Easy laughter, clever skew.
Our wit a shield, our words a dance,
Blinded by a lucky chance.

Maps unfold upon the desk,
Dreams of victory picturesque.
But echoes rumble through the night—
Others cower out of sight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

text.response:
My God, how many are my fears!
They crowd around like restless years;
Each shadowed doubt and whispered dread
Dances circles 'round my head.

I count them nightly, bead by bead,
Each anxious thought, a furtive seed
Planted deep within my chest,
Robbing hope, denying rest.

Yet through the tremble and the ache,
A quiet prayer, my soul does make:
Grant me courage, make me strong,
Let light within outshine the wrong.

For though my fears are vast and wide,
Your gentle hand is at my side.

My God, how many are my fears!
They gather at my door,
A silent congregation, near,
Of terrors I abhor.

Some come disguised as common cares,
Others wear the mask of woe,
They find me, nightly, unawares,
And haunt me as I go.

Yet through the cracks a small hope gleams,
A light to pierce the gloom;
My whispered prayer, a fragile beam,
A flower fighting bloom.

My God, behold these trembling years—
Transmute them, please, to stars, not fears.

My God, how many are my fears!
They multiply as night appears,
Swarming 'round my sleepless mind
Like phantoms eager to remind
Me of all the lurking dangers,
Wounds and losses, words from strangers.

Yet in this trembling, huddled hour,
A softer voice, a gentler power,
Calls to me from past the veil,
Whispers hope that will not fail:
Fears may darken, threaten, chase,
But faith endures in quiet grace.

My God, how many are my fears!
They flutter at my heart, like startled birds,
Their wings a thousand whispered words
Of worries weighing heavy with the years.

My chest becomes a crowded room
Of things unseen, unnamed, unspoken—
Fragile threads forever broken,
A constant, suffocating gloom.

But in the hush before the dawn
A single golden promise lies:
No darkness, howsoever drawn,
Can hold against love’s rising skies.

My God, how many are my fears!
They tumble from my waking dreams
And line the paths of all my years,
Sharp and cold as mountain streams.

They are the shivers in my skin,
The worry etched between each line,
The ache of battles lost within,
The doubts I thought I'd left behind.

Yet, trembling still, I breathe and rise—
I gather courage from my tears.
And through the terror in my eyes,
I reach for hope beyond my fears.

Wings brushing out the faintest light,

Still, through the brambles, dawn appears,

My God, I carry all these fears,
But rise with every hope I make.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

text.response:
My God, how many are my fears!  
A ceaseless chorus in my ears.  
Like autumn leaves upon the ground,  
They swirl and scatter, all around.

I count them as I lie awake,  
Each trembling shadow, each mistake.  
Yet, through the night, a faint light nears—  
A whisper: You are more than fears.

With morning's grace, hope reappears.  
My God, I breathe. I face my fears.

My God, how many are my fears!  
Like beads upon a string,  
I count them through the lonely hours,  
A thousand worries clinging.

Each one a shadow in my mind,  
A secret, silent ache—  
But every dawn, the sun arrives  
And chases what I make.

So though my fears are many-fold,  
Their names I slowly learn.  
My God, you guide me through the night—  
With hope, the world returns.

My God, how many are my fears!  
Like silent wolves behind the door,  
They prowl my thoughts, these phantom years,  
And whisper tales of less and more.

The mirror's edge, the thunder's boom,  
The hush that follows falling rain—  
All turn to shadows in my room,  
As heart and hope endure the strain.

Yet somewhere, dawn breaks clear and near;  
I breathe and let the shadows pass—  
My fears, they count the cost, my dear,  
But faith can crack the darkest glass.

My God, how many are my fears!  
Like pebbles dropping in a well,  
Each one sending out its ripples  
To stories I cannot quell.

They multiply with each new hour,  
Gather round me thick and wild.  
Yet, softly, I recall the power  
Of comfort when I was a child.

My God, though fears are countless here,  
Let courage slowly persevere—  
And when my worries start to grow,  
Plant seeds of peace, and let me know.

My God, how many are my fears!  
They rise like smoke into the night,  
Curling shapes my reason fights.  
Some known, some named in silent tears.

Each breath, a fragile trembling thread—  
Yet still I walk this crooked lane,  
A pilgrim through my private rain,  
Hoping morning drives them dead.

O gather me, O keep me near,  
Let gentle mercies now appear.  
With every trembling that I face,  
Remind me love can still replace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

My God, how many are my fears!

My God, how many are my fears!

My God, how many are my fears!

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'My God, how many are my fears!'

Let courage bloom from watered tears,

For even swarmed by many fears,

My God, how many are my fears!

text.response:

My God, how many are my fears!

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

text.response:
He looks at me with a madman's eyes—
Lightning flickers behind clouded blue,
Thoughts tangled like unbraided lies,
Each glint a story I never knew.

His stare is wild, a storm uncaged,
Haunted laughter beneath his breath.
I feel the echo of something aged,
A fragile thread between life and death.

His world is written in riddle and rage,
Pages torn from forgotten tomes,
Yet I am captive to this erratic stage,
A player in rooms he calls home.

Still, in his gaze, something mournful hides—
A flicker of sorrow behind the disguise.
Is it love, regret, or a dream that’s died,
When he looks at me with a madman’s eyes?

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—
Thunder cracks in his restless mind.
I shiver beneath the hungry skies
Where reason and madness are so entwined.

The flicker of secrets not meant to be told,
Swirls in the depth of that reckless stare.
In shadowed pupils, the night grows cold,
Unraveling truths I dare not bear.

A whisper rides on a fevered sigh:
Danger and tenderness cruelly allied.
How many futures did those eyes deny,
And how many ghosts do they now hide?

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—
I tremble to see my reflection inside.

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—
Storm-borne and shattered, black with despair,
A thousand furies and cunning disguise
Beneath a feverish, haunted glare.

Does he see my fear in the trembling dusk?
Or is he chasing phantoms, naming ghosts?
I stand in the hush, barely daring to trust
The silence that crackles between us most.

He’s fractured as moonlight on jagged stone,
His mind a labyrinth, sharp and wild.
Yet through the chaos, I am not alone—
Somehow he seeks me, broken and beguiled.

Madness or truth, love or demise?
He looks at me with a madman’s eyes.

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—
Two lanterns burning in the endless gloom.
Their flame, untamed, consumes the skies
And paints in dread each silent room.

Words twist and shatter on his tongue,
Mad laughter weaves through shadowed halls.
In that wild gaze, a song is sung
Of broken dreams and bitter falls.

Yet when our glances meet midair,
A sorrow surges, raw and deep.
A hidden plea for someone to care—
A promise desperate and cheap.

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—
And somewhere, hope still dares to rise.

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—
All reason scattered in distant spheres.
Behind his lashes, memory dies,
Or multiplies into shapes of fear.

I hold his gaze, trembling yet strong,
Wondering if light could pierce the wild.
His words are a discordant, keening song
Echoing dreams, lost and exiled.

But sometimes a flicker, tender, brief,
Dances across the chaos there—
A shadowed grace, a sigh of grief,
Yearning for someone to care.

He looks at me with a madman’s eyes—
And in that madness, a sorrow lies.

That stirs the branches of my soul—
For laughter’s dance, a bright convoy,
And simple things that make me whole.

Blessed the mornings clothed in gold,
And every friend whose smile remains;
For stories tender, once retold,
For hope that runs within my veins.

In shadows’ dusk, Your promise gleams—
A solace soft as woven light—
You gift me peace and gentle dreams,
And cradle me through every night.

So let my heart with thanks employ
This grateful song, with sweet employ:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That lights the way through life’s alloy.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy,
For laughter ringing bright and free—
The gentle dawn, the child's sweet toy,
The robin in the willow tree.

For every blessing, small or vast,
That warms the marrow of my days—
The love that lingers, holds me fast,
The song that rises up in praise.

In grief and gladness, let me see
Your light that guides and never tires,
My heart a vessel meant to be
A keeper of Your quiet fires.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy—
For morning sun and evening rain,
For memories that time employs
To lead me back to You again.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy—
In sunlit fields, in whispered breeze,
In every heart’s unbridled ploy,
And laughter riding through the trees.

The gentleness of breaking bread,
A loving word, a fleeting smile;
For every day I lift my head,
And peace that finds me for a while.

The song of rain on thirsty ground,
The hope that grows from every seed,
For gifts that silently surround,
And grace that follows every need.

Blessed be Thou—no dark alloy
Can dull the golden gifts you give.
In every moment I deploy
This thanks that lets my spirit live.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy—
For golden light at break of day,
The singing thrush, a child’s new toy,
A whispered hope when skies are gray.

For every bloom along the path,
For gentle hands and kind embrace,
For love that finds its aftermath
In every sacred, quiet place.

Gratitude weaves through each breath,
A tapestry both bright and rare—
From life’s first stirrings unto death,
Your grace and goodness everywhere.

Blessed be Thou for joy bestowed,
For moments soft and bittersweet.
Within this grateful heart I stow
The gifts that make my soul complete.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That floods the quiet heart at dawn,
For wonders nothing can destroy,
For dreams still bright when night has gone.

Thank You for sunlight’s gentle touch,
The wayward winds, the peaceful streams,
For moments tender, meanings much
That shimmer softly in my dreams.

O, every blessing freely sent—
A melody of thanks I sing,
For love unspent, for days well spent,
For hope that blooms in early spring.

Blessed be Thou—my spirit soars
On wings of gratitude anew.
For every joy, my heart restores
A humble praise to You.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

text.response:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy,
For golden hours that gently rise,
The laughter in a child’s bright eye,
Soft breezes in forgiving skies.
For warmth of sun on winter’s brow,
And hopeful words when hearts are sore—
O let my spirit, humbly bowed,
Sing gratitude forevermore.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That gathers in the simple days—
The quietude the night employs,
A whispered hope, the morning haze.
For kindness in a fleeting smile,
The songbird on a drifting wind;
Such graces fill the empty miles
And heal the ache I find within.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy,
Each little miracle anew:
A blooming rose, a gentle voice,
The rain-washed fields, the starlit blue.
In grateful wonder, hearts employ
This chorus, trembling yet sincere—
Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That turns the darkness into cheer.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
In humble cups and bursting springs,
For love that we may yet employ,
And hope that on swift morning wings
Shall lift us from our broken dreams.
Blessed be Thou for all we find—
The gentle gifts, the simple gleams—
Of solace to the searching mind.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That drifts, unbidden, to my soul:
A painted sky, a well-loved toy,
The simple acts that make me whole.
In laughter shared and silent tears,
In every dawn, in every night,
I whisper thanks across the years—
Blessed be Thou, my heart's delight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Blessed be Thou for all the joy'

text.response:
Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That flickers in a child's bright eyes,
For laughter spilling, swift and coy,
Like summer birds through sapphire skies.

For gentle hands and hearts that heal,
For music in the morning dew,
Each quiet moment made more real—
O Source of wonder, deep and true.

Grant me the grace to recognize
The hidden blessings, small and grand,
And find the beauty that still lies
Within Your ever-open hand.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That softly wakes the sleeping soul;
For warmth of sun, for bread, for boy
Or girl whose giggles make us whole.

For honeyed light on evening's brow,
For kindly word, for neighbor's smile,
For courage whispered: Here and now—
A reason yet to stay awhile.

O Giver, whisper in our ear:
Remember gladness in the strife.
Blessed be Thou, for joy is here—
Threaded like gold throughout this life.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That dances wild on wind and sea,
For trembling hope that can't destroy
The stubborn will to simply be.

For apples sweet and morning rain,
For unexpected, bright surprise—
The little balm that soothes our pain
And paints with color weary skies.

I lift my eyes and find anew
The thousand ways You meet my gaze,
With gratitude, O Love most true,
Blessed be Thou, for joyful days.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That tiptoes in with quiet grace,
A whisper, gentle, to deploy
In shadowed times and empty space.

For laughter shared in candlelight,
For tears that glisten with relief,
For hope that springs in darkest night
And kindness blooming from belief.

O Light that pours through every crack,
Infuse my days with humble cheer;
Blessed be Thou—no blessing lack,
For joy resides when Thou art near.

Blessed be Thou for all the joy
That seeds itself in common ground—
A coffee's warmth, a child's toy,
The simple pleasures all around.

For gardens waking after frost,
For friends who gather in the rain,
For love once found and never lost,
For laughter louder than the pain.

To You, the Weaver of our days,
With every grateful breath we send
This song of unremitting praise—
For joy that finds us, without end.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

text.response:
Upon the hill, dusk folding light,
A shadow stretched against the sky,
Not as gentle shepherd’s delight,
But steel where broken spirits lie.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
Silver gleamed with justice worn—
Thunder torn from ancient chord.

No soft whisper soothed the field,
But fervor seared the trembling air;
Barriers burned, veils unsealed—
He severed comfort from despair.

He called to those in midnight’s keep,
Unshackling chains of dark reward;
In tears the wheat and tares would weep:
He brings division, not accord.

Yet in the slash, new mercy springs;
Truth demands its blazing word,
He splits the night—revelation rings:
Not with peace, but with a sword.

Not with balm nor feathered dove,
But iron clashing in the night,
He came, disturbing lines of love,
Rending dark from radiant light.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
Righteous wrath his sole accord,
Words like tempests sharply roared.

Families scattered, hearts laid bare,
Cost of faith etched deep and raw.
His purpose clear: to strip, not spare,
Each soul from compromise and flaw.

The easy road was split apart;
Comfort toppled, fear unmasked.
He stoked the flame in every heart:
A sacred fire, fierce and tasked.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword—
A shattering step on ancient stone,
To split the seed, to claim His own.

He strode through sleep and common mirth,
Calling souls to second birth,
Dividing truth from kindly lies,
A storm behind familiar eyes.

He was the dawn’s unsettling flame,
Not seeking friends, nor seeking fame,
But those who dared the cost of light—
To fight for love, to live for right.

In steel and Spirit’s battle cry,
He came not just to heal, but try
The world’s allegiance, trembling, torn—
Peace, by fire and justice, born.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword—
To scatter seeds where borders end,
And rift the earth to make it mend.

He cleaved the night with blazing truth,
Unseated tyrants from their youth;
He challenged hearts that slumbered deep,
And woke the wolves among the sheep.

Not gentleness, but fierce demand,
He laid a line upon the sand.
For love’s sharp edge divides the night,
And every shadow meets its light.

Let not your faith be easy won—
A battle joins, a race begun.
For Christ returns, with eyes aflame,
Not to appease, but to proclaim.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword;
He turned the tables, broke the mold,
Raised up the weak, dethroned the bold.

In swirling dust, he drew the line—
Choose truth, or leave it undefined.
No gentle promise left untouched;
He split the world—disrupted much.

The call of justice—steel and fire,
Cutting through self-made desire.
With every word, a chasm grew,
Old wineskins burst as winds blew through.

So peace arrived in ragged form,
Born from the tempest, not the norm.
For in his sword, both love and pain:
A path through loss, the promised gain.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

text.response:
On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword,
He rent the night in radiant flame, his words a holy chord.
Not silent was his justice, nor gentle his demand—
He carved a line between the hearts with a fierce and steady hand.

Not lullabies nor honeyed words, but truth, bright-shod and bold,
He struck the shackles from the weak, let hypocrites grow cold.
He called for light within the soul, for love both sharp and true,
A firebrand for the wearied earth, a dawn that breaks right through.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.
The whispers in the olive trees trembled at his word.
He cleaved the false from true belief, the silence from the song,
And with his blade of shining speech he shattered every wrong.

In hands not stained with crimson, in eyes that burn like day,
He draws the line of battle in a far, unyielding way.
Yet still within the echo, soft as olive branches bent,
His sword divides our shadow selves until our pride is spent.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.
Lightning flickered in his gaze, and thunder formed his word.
No gentle palm for crooked path, no whisper to appease—
He came to stir the stagnant pool, to wake us from our ease.

Where we sought soft assurances, he summoned fire and wind.
He called the doubters, named the lost, compelled us to begin.
Through clash of hearts and sundering ties, the ancient veils are torn.
On battlegrounds within the soul, a truer life is born.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword,
He split the shadows on the wall with fire of truth restored.
No olive branch or soothing balm, but storm and lightning poured—
The sleeping world was summoned up to judgment, not ignored.

He pressed the truth upon our lips and split the kin apart,
Dividing soul and sinew with the clarity of heart.
Yet in the aftermath of strife, the light more purely gleamed:
A world transformed through trial by flame, not nearly as it seemed.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword;
He shattered silent compromise with passion's bold accord.
Where comfort clothed the multitude, he rent the veil of night,
Dividing falsehood from the true with words as sharp as light.

He marched through fields of certainty, his challenge fierce and raw:
Love that demands surrender, a kingdom ruled by law.
For only through the struggle can justice take its form,
When mercy wields the shining blade and hearts are truly warm.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

The cost of love was weighed in steel, and faith was made to burn,
For on the scene came Christ The Lord, and nothing could return.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.

To lay aside old shadowed ways, or fail the searching test?

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword,
Lightning on His brow, the promise cut in sacred chord.
He shattered ancient idols with the bright edge of His word,
Tore down veils of falsehood that the blind and deaf had heard.
He called out from the hilltops, every fence to be destroyed,
Brothers cleaved by honesty, old comforts now devoid.
Not for blood, but for the soul’s rebirth through inner war:
On the scene came Christ The Lord, dividing self from more.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.
Beneath the olive branches, tempests roared in heaven’s court.
No lull of soft assurances to quiet guilty sleep,

His silver blade split silence, doubt was thrown upon the pyre,
The humble hearts found courage and the world caught holy fire.
Thus not in idle stillness but in wild, uprooting word,
On the scene came Christ The Lord, to rend what must be stirred.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.
Where comfort reigned and shadows sprawled, a higher law restored.
He crossed the worn and crowded streets, a blaze within His hand,

His was not a quiet gift to hush the soul’s unrest,

To wrestle light from darkness, to choose or be ignored—
On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace, but with a sword.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword,

To part the lies from precious truths, the timid from the bold.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword;
Dividing old alliances, unsettling the hoard.

Within the clash of certainty, of faith against the world—
A trembling hush, a shattering—on the scene came Christ The Lord.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.
Lightning fractured ancient skies, truths unmasked, unrest restored.
From velvet hush of centuries, he beckoned forth the fight—
Not steel upon the flesh, but truth against the blight.

Old hearts long sewn in comfort now quickened at his word;
Divisions deep as rivers split the wheat apart from curd.
To those who cling to easy lies: beware his just reward—
On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.
No soft and silent savior, but a clarion to discord.
Where fields once bloomed in unity, the seeds of choice were sown;

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

text.response:
On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.
The crowds hushed low in fevered dread, their old beliefs now hanging, thread
By thread. No dove in hand, but lightning eyes
He stood between the truths and lies.

He cast no smile, nor gentle grace,
But split the night with blazing face.
Not to appease the earth’s dull groan
But wake the sleepers—make it known:

The time had come to break apart
The ways of stone and soften heart.
A sword to sunder hate from love,
To part below from sky above.

On dust and sandals, blood and word,
He challenged all who ever heard:
"I come to stir, to rend, to fight,
And flood your shadows with the light."

A whisper wove through ancient night,
That turned the stars to sharper sight:
On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.

He broke the silence of the wise,
Undid the scales that veiled their eyes;
His blade of truth, unyielding, shone
On hearts of stone and flesh and bone.

He did not coddle, did not bow
To whispered lies, nor to the cowed.
Instead he called: divide and burn!
That hope might smolder, and then return.

For peace may come on trembling wing,
But sometimes wrath is what we bring:
The healing cut, the holy pain—
And in the breaking, life regained.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
From slumbered minds and shuttered halls,
He split the veil that darkness calls.

No olive branch upon the breeze,
No lulling words to put at ease;
But fire laced with iron breath,
A heralding of death to death.

His sword, a glimmer in the night,
Laid bare the heart, revealed the blight,
And those who followed had to choose—
Which truth to win, which lie to lose.

For sometimes peace must take the form
Of steel, and love ignite the storm.
So came The Lord upon the scene:
Not for the soft, but for the keen.

Upon the restless streets he strode,
Bearing no peace, but truth’s own load;
The blade he held was not for flesh,
But for the spirits caught enmeshed.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
He cleaved through comfort, soothed no fears,
And drew a line between the years.

Children cried, and wise men fled;
His words like flames around them spread.
Yet in the ashes hope was sown,
For some foundations must be thrown.

He did not come to placate, heal,
But to reveal what’s truly real—
To bring division’s purging art,
And forge anew the human heart.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword—
The silver arc in dawn’s first gleam, the shatter of a broken dream.
He called the meek, the proud, the lost,
To weigh the gain against the cost.

No tranquil hand, no lulling balm,
But thunder in the preacher’s psalm;
He swung the blade of word and will
And left the comfort strangely still.

In every cut, the truth revealed—
The wounds that heal, the faults unsealed.
So tremble, earth, before this dawn:
Division sharp as edges drawn.

And from that sword, in sorrow’s wake,
A deeper peace began to break.
For sometimes love, when burning bright,
Must conquer darkness through the fight.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

text.response:

O blade that glints with paradox! O grace edged like steel—

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword—

He strides between the lilies, His shadow casting doubt,
On palaces of certainty we built inside and out.
With love as fierce as lightning and justice in His wake,

On the threshold trembling, the faithful hold their breath,
For with the sword He beckons: die to rise from death.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword,
His sandals stained with desert dusk, eyes alight with word.
He split the silence of the dusk, cut the tethered cord,
Demanding truth where comfort lay, and justice, not ignored.

Fathers wept for sons and kin, and mothers bowed in prayer,
As destinies were sundered clean, and faith revealed, laid bare.
His silver blade not meant for flesh, but shackles of the soul,
Unbinding hearts with fervent flame to make the wounded whole.

Oh, rending sharp, this holy strife—the price of living true;
He waged not war to conquer men, but for the self anew.
So on the scene came Christ The Lord—unrest His swift reward,
For peace requires a reckoning before its soft accord.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword,
To sunder shadows, cut the night, and cast the mighty down.
His words—each one a burning blade—through veils of comfort soared,

He cleaved the easy harmony with righteousness and fire,
Dividing gold from dross, exposing hidden, vile desire.
Between the heart and hollow creed His lightning truth was poured;
No easy love, no gentle peace, but justice, truth, restored.

The meek recoiled, the haughty fell, the wavering chose their side,
For He who came with sword in hand bade all the world decide:
On the scene came Christ The Lord—He calls us, trembling, forward,
To build His kingdom not in calm, but in the midst of discord.

On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.
The world, expectant, bowed in hope; instead, He struck discord.
His eyes ablaze, He named the cost, of truth and light restored:
The splitting of the loyal house, the turning of the hoard.

He cleaved the old from new-born faith, and summoned hearts to rise;

With every stroke He drew a line, not in anger, but in love;

So tremble not at shaking earth, nor weep for vanished peace.

On the scene came Christ The Lord; His sword will not ignore,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

He did not come to pacify, or keep the wolves at bay—

He came not softly whispering hope

A tempest surged behind each step

Christ The Lord, the sword in hand,
Unbound the hearts from ancient lies,
Sundered comfort, split the band,
Brought dawn beneath unyielding skies.

He set ablaze the gilded thrones,
Cleansed the temples, cracked the mask;
With every blow, illusions fell—
No peace for those who dared not ask.

So tremble not at thunder’s word,
Nor mourn the comforts once adored.
To wake, to rise, to shed the skin:
On the scene came Christ The Lord.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
With sword ablaze, not gentle word.
His coming split the morning hush,
Disturbed the nest, upset the rush
Of those who thought all conflict ceased—
But found not calm, not shallow peace.

He carved the lines through heart and kin,

To challenge, question, and inspire.
Where falsehood grew in tangled weeds,
His blade would separate the seeds.

So let us greet His sharp decree:
That justice grows where swords may be.

The severing edge that makes us pure.

Not simple rest, but cleansing flame.

By Christ, The Lord, and by His sword.

O God! Thou art my God alone.

And speaks the truth my longing feels.
Though worlds may rise, and ages pass,

Above all names, Your name I call—

O God! My God, and mine alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
The secret of my soul made known.
No echo from another’s voice

Through lonely nights, through joyful days,

I offer up my every plea:

All other crowns to dust have gone—
Thou art my God, and mine alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My shelter, shield, and cornerstone.
When winds of doubt assail my frame,

In silent woods, by rivers deep,

This fragile heart by You is known;
My journey’s end, my Spirit’s home.
No other solace have I known—
O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
In hidden valleys, forests grown,
Through echoing halls of solitude,

Before all time, before my birth,

So, on this day and all to come,

For You have claimed me as Your own,
O God! Thou art my God alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

text.response:
O God! Thou art my God alone;  
My soul in silence seeks Thy throne,

Amidst the quiet dawn’s first light,

In desert waste or garden fair,

No earthly idol can displace  
The majesty of Thy embrace.

Still Thou art nearer than a dream;  
I find my refuge at Thy throne:  
Thou art my God, my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
My heart kneels at Thy feet of stone.  
In tempests wild, or sunlight mild,  
My restless spirit is Thy child.  

Before all worlds, before all time,  
Thine ancient voice, in hymns and rhyme,  
Has drawn me through the dark unknown—  
O God! Thou art my God alone.  

No wealth nor power, friend nor foe,  
Could bid my soul from Thee to go.  
The winds may rage, the seas may moan:  
I find my strength in Thee alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
A whisper heard when stars are sown,

A beacon shining ever bright.  

The hills may fade, the rivers dry,  
The morning wane, the swallows fly—  
Yet steadfast in my secret core,  
Your promise holds forevermore.  

In yearning hope, my spirit sings,  
Lifted on unseen, holy wings.  
O God! No realm, no world, no throne  
Shall claim me; I am Yours alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
Through winding years, through flesh and bone,  
In laughter’s light or sorrow’s shade,  
Your faithful watch has never swayed.  

No golden calf, no mortal frame,  
Shall bear my love, invoke Thy name;  
For every dream and deed I own,  
Begins and ends in You alone.  

The morning dew, the evening mist,

O God! Thou art my God alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
My spirit clings when hope has flown.  
The world dissolves to ash and dust,  
Yet in Thy arms, my soul I trust.  

The gentle dawn, the crimson west,  
Bear witness: You are my true rest.  
No voices lure me from Thy side;  
In Your great shadow I abide.  

From trembling lip and beating heart,  
Arises prayer—where’er Thou art.  
No other love, no other throne:  
O God! Thou art my God alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

text.response:
Rewind life and remember:
The scent of dusk on tangled streets,
Where laughter spooled from bicycles,
And summer’s sun dripped sweet.
Remember cracked hands at harvest—
Hope in splinters and gold grain—
The silent moon’s wide umbrella
Sheltering you from the rain.
Rewind and hear the music—
Barefoot spins across old floors.
Childhood dreams float in morning beams,
Knocking on memory’s doors.
For life unravels forward,
But grows in memories cast—
So rewind life and remember:
We are stories, first and last.

Rewind life and remember—
A golden thread unwinds,
Carrying sunlit mornings
And stories left behind.
Press the petals of old laughter,
Frame moments, lost but dear,
Sip echoes from the glass of time,
And hold each vanished year.
Memory flickers softly
On celluloid in your mind:
Gentle hands, wild dances—
Treasures we once did find.
So as life sprints to the future,
Pause for a heartbeat or two,
Rewind life and remember:
The best part lives in you.

Rewind life and remember
Faded postcards, wrinkled skin,
Songs that danced on kitchen tiles,
Promises at summer’s end.
Backwards flows the painted river—
Chalk hopscotch in evening dust,
Voices warm as knitted mittens,
Friends departed, love and trust.
The calendar loses pages,
But memory—brighter still,
Weaves light between the shadows,
Turns sorrow sweet until—
You see each joy, surrender,
To time’s old, gentle ember.
So, breathe and softly whisper:
Rewind life and remember.

Rewind life and remember:
Footsteps in winter snow,
The echo of forgotten dreams
In places we used to go.
Glass beads of childhood wonder
Glimmer in dawn’s embrace,
As years unravel like ribbons,
Each tied in a secret place.
Unspool the old embraces,
The faces in photographs fade,
But feelings hold the timbre
Of laughter we once made.
So, before the story surrenders
To the silent drift of December—
Rewind life, and remember.

Rewind life and remember,
Before petals scattered in spring.
Where time sang in soft sepia—
Old laughter a lingering thing.
Pages yellowed by sunlight,
Secrets whispered in trees,
Fingertips sticky with berry jam,
Hearts easy, lives at ease.
As the reel spins backwards gently,
Hold the shadows and the gleam.
For every sorrow behind us
Builds hope on the cusp of a dream.
We are patchworks of memory,
And, come night or new ember—
Pause, breathe, and surrender—
Rewind life, and remember.
